thick.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if something is thick, there is a large distance or a larger distance than usual between its two opposite surfaces or sides
thick.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a thick slice of homemade bread
thick wool socks  (=socks that are heavy and warm)
If you want a thicker blanket, there are more here in the closet.
The meat is done when the thickest part turns from pink to white.
The furniture was thick with dust  (=there was thick dust on the furniture).
thick.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: measuring a particular distance between two opposite sides or surfaces of something
thick.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: How thick should the glass in the tank be?
This layer of brain tissue is no thicker than 2 mm.
The walls are about two meters thick.
thick.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: growing very close together or having a lot of leaves
thick.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: birds hiding in the thick undergrowth
The walls were thick with ivy.
thick.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: filling the air, and difficult to see through or breathe in
thick.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The air was thick with cigarette smoke.
thick.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: almost solid, and therefore flowing very slowly, or not flowing at all
thick.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: For a thicker gravy, add more flour.
thick.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: having a lot of hair or fur
thick.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: She ran her fingers through her thick brown hair.
thick.translation[0].definitions[6].note: (as) thick as two short planks (=very stupid)
thick.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: He’s a nice guy, but he’s a bit thick.
thick.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if someone has a thick accent, the way they speak shows clearly which particular place or part of a country they come from
thick.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Olga speaks English with a thick Russian accent.
thick.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if someone’s voice is thick, it is not as clear or high as usual, for example because they are upset
thick.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Bill’s voice was thick and gruff.
Her voice was thick with emotion.
thick.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: containing a lot of people or things
thick.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: The cod were so thick in the water that they caught thousands very quickly.
The roads were thick with holiday traffic.
thick.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: thickly. Many teachers think this is not correct English
